title.narrative: Emergency Control of Leishmaniasis Amongst Recently Displaced People in North West Syria.

description.narrative:
The dynamics of war have conspired in Syria to create the perfect mix for the proliferation of the Leishmania parasite and its vector, the sandfly. Sandflies breed in uncollected waste, cracks and crevices, and in the rubble of destroyed infrastructure created by conflict and displacement. Furthermore, the most common species of Leishmania parasite use host reservoirs such as humans, rodents, and dogs. Not only are the non-human hosts, especially rodents, boosted by the detritus of war, but the amassing of IDPs in encampments greatly enhances the female sandflies’ ability to find a blood meal to nourish the development of eggs, and thus to transmit infection.
As per CCCM cluster information from late February, 948,000 people have been displaced in NWS between December 1st, 2019 and February 23rd, 2020. These people have been displaced from areas with high incidence of cutaneous (CL) and visceral leishmaniasis (VL) and have reduced access to diagnostic and treatment services due to their displacement and the disruption and overload of health services in their current locations. MENTOR has noted a dramatic increase in the caseload and incidence of CL (increases of 3-4 times the caseload per month) in Harim, Afrin and Azaz districts. In addition, there has been an outbreak of cases of VL in these districts with 11 cases diagnosed by MENTOR in the past 8 weeks. There is a desperate need now for an increase in leishmaniasis control activities in these areas to address this recent outbreak of leishmaniasis. Through this project, The MENTOR Initiative will continue to partner with stakeholders and communities to ensure that the most vulnerable receive:
1-Health Access to effective diagnostic and treatment services: A combination of static health facilities and mobile clinics (MC) will be supported with both an essential supply chain of diagnostic and case management commodities and materials, and through technical training and coaching.
2-Information, Education and Communication/Behavioural Change Campaign (IEC/BCC) Information about leishmaniasis and its transmission. MENTOR will run a combined IEC/BCC to ensure households are empowered to prevent leishmaniasis transmission within their household. This will be done by various media and delivery strategies, to maximise uptake and correct utilization of leishmaniasis prevention and case management services.
